docs.lead_paragraph: Facing legal and regulatory challenges by New Jersey officials and consumer groups, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey called off plans yesterday to merge with a big for-profit Midwest insurance company, Anthem Inc. The merger, which did not involve a payment, would have created one of the nation's biggest health insurers. Blue Cross plans across the country have been trying to merge and become for-profit companies as they compete with private insurance companies that have also been consolidating in a series of big mergers. All the insurers want to spread the enormous costs of the new computer systems they need for their managed health care business.

headline.main: New Jersey Blue Cross Takeover By For-Profit Insurer Is Canceled

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1948, Clarence Buikema opened a 3,000-square-foot hardware store in this town 30 miles west of Chicago and made a home for his family in the upstairs apartment. Competitors in the area, which was then mainly rural, were few and far between. It was a start so quaintly at odds with the hardware business today that Kyle Buikema, his grandson, laughs as he recounts it. The prairie here has fast-forwarded into wall-to-wall suburbia. And Mr. Buikema, who oversees what has become a chain of five home-and-garden mini-warehouses that are as much as 10 times as large as the original shop, spends his days dodging commercial crossfire his grandfather could never have imagined.

headline.main: Independents Have a Weapon Against the 'Big Boxes'
headline.kicker: In Hardware War, Cooperation May Mean Survival

docs.abstract: In fast-growing hardware business, retailing cooperatives like Ace Hardware and Servistar are locked in battle for market share with retail giants like Home Depot; co-op structure has let local hardware stores compete, though their growth has lagged behind big chains; big co-ops include Ace; Cotter & Co, whose members operate under True Value name; Servistar Coast to Coast Corp, and Hardware Wholesalers Inc; hardware dealer Kyle Buikema, who runs five Ace Hardware stores in Chicago area, comments; charts; tables; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 On Eve of Audit, Swiss Find More Accounts One week before the start of formal audits of their wartime accounts next week, Switzerland's banks have told investigators that they recently discovered hundreds of accounts that may have belonged to Holocaust victims, and thousands more opened during the war years by Swiss nationals who may have been acting as agents for others seeking to hide their assets from Nazi forces. A1 Yeltsin Flexing Federal Muscle President Boris N. Yeltsin planned to remove Yevgeny Nazdratenko from his post as Governor of the Primorsky region in the Russian Far East, a spokesman for Mr. Yeltsin said. Crime and corruption are rampant in the immense and strategic region, which includes the port of Vladivostok. Mr. Yeltsin has never before removed an elected leader. A3 Pope Bids Farewell to Poland Pope John Paul II ended an 11-day trip to Poland with a farewell address in Cracow. He urged his fellow Poles to unite around common goals and applauded them for meeting the challenges of the transition to democracy. He often spoke against abortion during his visit, but also urged the Polish church not to meddle in politics. A14 U.S. Approves Loan for Croatia A $13 million loan for a redevelopment project in Croatia was approved by an affiliate of the World Bank. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had threatened 10 days earlier to isolate Croatia economically for failing to comply with the Bosnian peace accords, but the United States approved the loan, saying that since then President Franjo Tudjman had announced ''positive things.'' A13 Brazzaville Battle Continues Government troops fought a private militia for a sixth day in Brazzaville, the capital of the Republic of Congo. Hundreds of people were killed, said officials close to the former dictator whose militia was battling Government forces. Foreigners and local residents, many seeking to flee the city, reported many deaths. A5 Coup Leaders Set Their Price The leaders of a coup in Sierra Leone have demanded $46 million to step down and allow the return of the civilian President they ousted last month, officials close to the junta said. They said the money would be shared among a total of about 35 mutinous soldiers and rebels of the Revolutionary United Front who have allied themselves with the army since the May 25 coup. Other officials denied the claim. A7 Hunger Seen in North Korea An American relief expert recently returned from North Korea said he had seen hundreds of people combing scrublands for edible weeds and malnourished schoolchildren too weak to stand. Widespread reports of food shortages and the prospect of a serious famine have been difficult to confirm in the isolated Communist regime. A8 NATIONAL A16-23, B10-12 Car Safety Plan Would Bar Children From Front Seats The National Transportation Safety Board asked the 50 states to make it illegal for a child to sit in the front seat of a car because of the danger from airbags. It also recommended that automakers install recorders to gather crash data similar to the information collected by ''black boxes'' on airplanes, in an effort to measure the effectiveness of airbags and seat belts. A1 Deaths Tied to Trucks Rise The rising number of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks on the nation's roads, combined with the increasing weight of these light trucks, poses a growing danger to car occupants and pedestrians, the Transportation Department concluded in its first study of the issue. A20 Clinton Rejects Tax Plan President Clinton rejected the Republican blueprint for apportioning proposed Federal tax cuts, saying it shortchanges the middle class and violates the terms of the balanced budget package agreed to by both parties last month. B12 McVeigh's Beliefs Heard Lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh, in their effort to save his life, showed a Federal Court jury magazine articles and videotapes about the Federal raid at Waco, Tex., which they said convinced him the Government had declared war on the American people. A19 U.S. Students Score Well American fourth-graders scored above the international average on standardized tests in math and science, according to a new study that also pointed to a mysterious sag in students' relative skills by eighth grade. B9 Group to Pick New Leader Former Representative Randy Tate, who was elected to Congress in the Republican wave of 1994 and ousted just two years later, will succeed Ralph Reed as executive director of the Christian Coalition, say those close to the selection process. A16 Flood Protest Closes Senate Democrats forced Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, to shut down the Senate to protest Republicans' handling of an $8.6 billion emergency aid bill that President Clinton vetoed on Monday. Before he was forced to end business early, Mr. Lott had proposed that Congress approve the most critical parts of the relief bill and negotiate separately two provisions that Mr. Clinton objected to. B12 Chemical Kills Professor A Dartmouth College chemistry professor has died from exposure to a rare form of mercury in what college officials believe is only the fourth such reported death attributable to the substance since it was first synthesized more than 130 years ago. Karen E. Wetterhahn, 48, died about 10 months after spilling a few drops of dimethylmercury on her disposable latex gloves during a laboratory experiment. B10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 70% of City Residents Back Rent Control Laws in Poll New York City residents by an overwhelming margin support regulations that keep rents below what the market will bear and do not want state rent ceilings to expire on Sunday, according to the latest New York Times poll. In margins of at least 70 percent they believe the laws are necessary to provide affordable housing and to prevent rents from soaring. Opinions are more closely divided when residents are asked how to implement controls. A1 Death Penalty Sought The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced that he would seek the death penalty for James Allen Gordon, a 24-year-old Jamaica man charged with murdering three women last July after the police said he raped one and tormented the others for hours over a $50 drug debt. B8 Murder Charge in Teen's Death Kalila Taylor, 20, was charged with the murder of a promising and popular senior at Riverhead High School who disappeared a year and a half ago. Officials said Ms. Taylor was driven to kill by jealousy over a boyfriend the two young women had shared. B8 2 Face Radiation Exposure In the second low-level radiation accident at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in six days, Energy Department officials said that two laboratory workers left work areas with particles of cobalt-60 radiation on their clothing. Neither worker was exposed to serious amounts of radiation, laboratory officials said. B8 SPORTS B14-21 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: End the stalemate on rent laws; a favor-the-rich tax plan; mishandling Russian uranium. Columns: Maureen Dowd, William Safire. BUSINESS DAY D1-19 Blue Cross Merger Off Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey called off plans to merge with a big for-profit Midwestern insurance company, Anthem Inc., after facing legal and regulatory challenges by New Jersey officials and consumer groups. The merger would have created one of the nation's biggest health insurers. D1 Utilities in Merger Talks The Energy Group, a British utility company, said it was in merger talks with Pacificorp, a West Coast power company. Energy Group said that if an offer emerged from Pacificorp that it expected it would be about $5.9 billion in cash. D1 Business Digest D1 OBITUARIES B13 LIVING C1-11 HEALTH C11 ARTS C13-19 Chronicle B2 Bridge C18 Crossword C16 Weather C10

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the anguish they say they went through to get an agreement to balance the budget within five years, what members of Congress are really doing now is what they enjoy most: cutting taxes and increasing spending. This is the first time in 15 years that they have allowed themselves this luxury. Ever since economists and politicians discovered in 1982 that the tax cuts enacted the year before would lead to an explosion in the budget deficit, the main item of business in Congress has been to decide who would pay higher taxes and who would be pinched by the belt-tightening needed to bring the deficit under control.

headline.main: Cutting Taxes a Luxury Now With Consequences Deferred

docs.abstract: Balanced budget accord would actually let deficit rise to some $90 billion next year, from $67 billion this year, allowing Congress luxury of cutting taxes and increasing spending on popular program for first time in 15 years; many tax breaks being considered are structured so that revenue loss would be small in next few years and mushroom later; some fiscal experts are skeptical that future President and Congress will show fiscal restraint needed to wipe out deficit as planned in 2001 and 2002 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICARE patients who are in conventional fee-for-service health plans are twice as likely to have eye surgery for cataracts as those in a large Western health maintenance organization, a California study has found. The study suggests either that many people in fee-for-service plans are being operated on unnecessarily or that many in the H.M.O. are being denied needed surgery, the researchers said. That the rate of cataract surgery was lower in the H.M.O. came as little surprise to the researchers, given that health maintenance organizations restrict patients' access to specialists like ophthalmologists, who perform the surgery. Previous studies found that the rates of other kinds of elective surgery, like hysterectomy and appendectomy, were lower in H.M.O.'s. The H.M.O. in the latest study was not identified.
docs.abstract: California study finds Medicare patients in conventional fee-for-service health plans are twice as likely to have eye surgery for cataracts as those in a large Western health maintenance organization; suggests either that many in fee-for-service plans are being operated on unnecessarily or that many patients in HMO's are being denied needed surgery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Community Care Services of Mount Vernon, N.Y., said yesterday that it was the target of a Federal investigation into allegations of improper payments involving Medicare. The United States Justice Department notified the company that Alan T. Scheinwald, the chief executive of the company; Allan C. Goldfeder, chief operating officer, and the company are targets of the inquiry, which involves health care services provided outside New York State. Federal authorities have searched the company's headquarters.

docs.lead_paragraph: A BRIGHT, fresh-looking Vanna White smile can often compensate for less attractive features and take years off a person's face. With dental decay now less troublesome, more people are turning their attention to improving the appearance of their teeth. For some, orthodontics to change the positioning of the teeth is the prime concern. But for ever-increasing numbers of patients, the issue is whitening of discolored teeth. At an international symposium last fall, experts in esthetic dentistry reviewed the safety and effectiveness of various treatments to remove unsightly stains from teeth. Their findings were published in April as a supplement to The Journal of the American Dental Association.
docs.abstract: Jane Brody's Personal Health column says that self-treatment with over-the-counter bleaching agents to gradually whiten teeth is risky and unwise and that dentist should be consulted before decision to try home bleaching; says overuse or misuse of bleaches to remove stains can injure gums or damage teeth; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was the old story: a lonely man, an encounter with a prostitute and a sheepish confession in the doctor's office a few days later. But the story has a modern twist. The patient left Dr. Barry S. Zingman's Bronx office a few weeks ago with treatment not only for the gonorrhea he had probably picked up from his misadventure, but also for the H.I.V. infection he ran a very small chance of acquiring.
docs.abstract: Powerful new drugs intended to treat established HIV infections are cautiously being tried as 'morning after' pills to forestall HIV transmission after risky sexual encounters; to date, no studies support such a practice; medications are not licensed for this purpose, and insurance companies typically do not pay for treatments with unlicensed medicine; but other pathways of HIV transmission are clearly disrupted by prompt use of drugs; some experts feel that analogy to sexual tranmission of infection is too powerful to ignore (M)
